title: People don't require Extraordinary Evidence to Believe Extraordinary Claims
description:
The truism that people require extraordinary evidence to believe extraordinary claims is just wrong. People simply don't work that way when it comes to most of what we believe because of how we believe. People need to work from internalized first draft maps that are nested within community maps. These maps are always being recalibrated via the data they receive, but the data is also always filtered by maps. This is because the world is simply too large. Even the discernment of an "event" is a product of the data/map/filter dynamic to separate it from the flow of everything by relevance realization according to the maps already being used. Data itself is filtered by these maps. 

The claim is simply a product of the imagined monarchical vision where we view the world from no-where and see things "as they are" which is something that human beings imagine they do but really can't. 

CS Lewis Miracles https://amzn.to/3nXhwW8
https://rationalwiki.org/wiki/Extraordinary_claims_require_extraordinary_evidence
@Jordan B Peterson on @Skeptic https://youtu.be/a6hGWCWQGVg
Tom Holland on @Unbelievable? https://youtu.be/FrxX3FVS_8I
Jordan Peterson and Sam Harris and @Bret Weinstein Vancouver 1 https://youtu.be/d-Z9EZE8kpo
The Body Keeps the Score https://amzn.to/3bbuTx4
Ironic Sadness of Deconstructed Evangelicals https://youtu.be/_qgVSwT-B38
